title: PE Daily: University of California Sues 8minute Solar | Citrix Nears Take Private Deal | TCV Goes Small | Calstrs Eyes Co-Investment Growth
text:
Today's Top Stories

The University of California system is suing 8minute Solar Energy LLC and Tom Buttgenbach, its co-founder and chief executive, seeking roughly $1.22 billion over the university's investment in several renewable-power projects, Luis Garcia reports for WSJ Pro Private Equity. However, in a motion filed Jan. 13 in response to the university regents' complaint, lawyers for Mr. Buttgenbach and 8minute said the allegations were frivolous and have been the subject of an arbitration proceeding initiated by co-investors in the projects. The lawsuit is an "attempt at a do-over" of the arbitration, Mr. Buttgenbach and 8minute said.

Cloud-computing company Citrix Systems Inc. is close to a roughly $13 billion deal to go private, continuing a spate of big leveraged buyouts that are powering record private-equity activity, Cara Lombardo and Miriam Gottfried report for the Wall Street Journal. Elliott Management Corp.'s private-equity arm, Evergreen Coast Capital, and Vista Equity Partners are near an agreement to pay $104 a share for the software company, according to people familiar with the matter. The deal could be announced Monday, the people said, assuming the talks don't fall apart or drag out.

Technology Crossover Ventures is forging deeper into the realm of startups with its newly formed Velocity team and a $460 million fund dedicated to the strategy, Ted Bunker writes for WSJ Pro Private Equity. With the strategy, TCV aims to capture value that might be missed by its larger funds, which tend to back more established companies, according to executives of the Menlo Park, Calif., growth investor. General Partner Tim McAdam said a review of roughly 1,000 deals in which TCV had the option to join revealed that in some cases it passed up a chance for big gains.

The California State Teachers' Retirement System aims to nearly double the size of its co-investment portfolio over the next five years and it plans to lean more heavily on investment staff to get there, Preeti Singh reports for WSJ Pro Private Equity. On Thursday, trustees of the $327.7 billion California pension, also known as Calstrs, approved policy changes that give its private-equity investment staff authority to approve larger investments directly in companies alongside fund sponsors and expand the types of opportunities staff can consider.

Deals

A view of the skyline of Malaysian capital Kuala Lumpur. Photo: Lim Huey Teng, Reuters

CVC Capital Partners has agreed to acquire a majority stake in Malaysian asset management firm Affin Hwang Asset Management Berhad from Affin Banking Group, marking the private-equity firm's sixth investment in Malaysia since 2007, according to a press release. CVC is backing the deal out of CVC Capital Partners Asia Fund V LP, which closed with $4.5 billion in 2020.

Brentwood Associates in Los Angeles is backing vegan cosmetics and fragrance maker Pacifica Beauty LLC. The private-equity firm is making a growth investment in the Carpinteria, Calif.-based company, according to a news release.

Midmarket firm One Equity Partners has agreed to acquire Trustmarque from publicly traded Capita plc for Â£111 million, the equivalent of $148.6 million, according to a news release. London-based Trustmarque provides information technology and services, including the resale of hardware and software.

Blackstone Inc. in New York is backing publicly traded VNET Group Inc., a provider of internet and data center services in China. The firm has agreed to purchase $250 million of convertible notes through its tactical opportunities strategy, according to a news release. The notes can be converted to the Beijing-based company's American depositary shares on a six-to-one basis at a price of $11 each. VNET operates sites serving more than 30 major cities in China.

Specialty firm Godspeed Capital Management in Palm Beach, Fla., has acquired technology services provider Savli Group Inc., according to a news release. The Woodbine, Md. company serves a variety of federal agencies and departments. Godspeed focuses on investing in U.S. government contractors.

SPAC Track

Correction: An earlier version of this newsletter item misidentified the SPAC that is acquiring BBQGuys as Brand Velocity Acquisition Corp, instead of Velocity Acquisition Corp., which is unrelated.

A blank-check company backed by Brand Velocity Partners, whose partners include former pro-football quarterback Eli Manning, has withdrawn its planned initial public offering of shares to raise $200 million, regulatory filings show. The filing didn't say why Brand Velocity Acquisition Corp was withdrawing the planned offering. A separate and unrelated special-purpose acquisition company, Velocity Acquisition Corp., has agreed to combine with online grilling-and-outdoor-products retailer ShoppersChoice.com LLC, which operates as BBQGuys, in a deal that valued the company at about $960 million. The Manning family, including Eli's brother and fellow Super Bowl champion Peyton Manning, are among the owners of BBQGuys, which is backed by Brand Velocity Partners.

Funds

Roark Capital Group, a private-equity firm known for backing companies with franchise and multilocation business models, has rounded up at least $4.6 billion so far for Roark Capital Partners VI LP and related parallel vehicles, regulatory filings indicate. The amount raised so far puts the fund close to a $5 billion offering amount indicated in the filings. Investors that have disclosed commitments to the fund include the New York State Common Retirement Fund and the Texas County & District Retirement System, according to WSJ Pro's LP Commitments database.

Warburg Pincus LLC is seeking $16 billion for its latest global private-equity fund, regulatory filings indicate. The offering amount for Warburg Pincus Global Growth 14, LP and related parallel vehicles, is modestly larger than the $15 billion the firm raised for its previous global fund effort in 2018.

People

CVC Capital Partners co-founder and Co-Chair Steve Koltes is stepping down from an active role at the firm on Oct. 1, 2022, according to a press release. Mr. Koltes will remain on the firm's board of directors in a non-executive capacity, the release stated.

SoftBank Group Corp.'s Marcelo Claure, the chief operating officer who helped clean up problems at the firm's investments including WeWork Inc. and Sprint Corp., is leaving the company, Kosaku Narioka and Liz Hoffman report for The Wall Street Journal. Mr. Claure is the latest lieutenant of SoftBank founder and Chief Executive Masayoshi Son to depart the Tokyo-based investment company, which runs the technology-focused Vision Fund and owns a large stake in Chinese e-commerce company Alibaba Group Holding Ltd.

Industry News

CCMP Capital Advisors LP is nearing the close of a multi-asset secondary process and has collected just under $1 billion to help extend its hold on two portfolio companies, people familiar with the matter told WSJ Pro Private Equity's Preeti Singh. The midmarket firm is raising a continuation fund to recapitalize facility management services provider BGIS and automotive aftermarket accessories company Truck Hero Inc. CCMP initially backed both companies out of CCMP Capital Advisors III LP, which wrapped up with $3.5 billion in 2014, the people said.

The ESG Data Convergence Project, an initiative aimed at improving how the private equity industry measures and monitors environmental, social and governance performance, has attracted over 100 general partners and limited partners to the partnership, according to a press release. The project's partner organizations represent $8.7 trillion in assets under management and more than 1,400 underlying portfolio companies, the release stated. Firms that have become involved recently with the project include Apollo Global Management, Ares Management, Goldman Sachs Asset Management, Hermes GPE and Oaktree Capital Management.

China's deliberate policy of reining in its freewheeling entrepreneurial class and reordering its investment priorities reveals what may be an inflection point in the Communist-run country's emerging competition with the U.S., Greg Ip writes for The Wall Street Journal. The divergence follows a long period during which the tech sectors in China and the U.S. shared much in common, after American entrepreneurs and their financial backers largely gave birth to China's venture-capital industry, according to scholar Sebastian Mallaby.

David Li, chairman and chief executive of Centurium Capital in Beijing, talks with The Wall Street Journal's Jing Yang about the private-equity firm's backing of Luckin Coffee Inc. and plans for the chain's future after taking control.

Blackstone Inc. has rolled up its industrial, logistics and warehouse properties in India into a single group, Horizon Industrial Parks, led by Rahul Pandit as chief executive, according to a news release. The New York firm plans to expand the group through local partnerships.
